A victim of domestic violence who survived her husband's gunshot attack has released graphic photos of her horrific injuries to encourage other women to speak out. 
Rachel Williams nearly died after her estranged husband Darren Williams burst into the hairdressers where she worked before blasting her in the legs with a double-barrelled shotgun. 
The monster later killed himself and was found hanged in the woods. 
The attack took place in August 2011 at the Carol Ann Hair Salon, Newport, six weeks after they split up. Rachel nearly died after her husband horrifically shot her at her workplace (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
Rachel, who has since remarried , told South Wales Argus : “When I look back I wasn't aware of the help available to domestic abuse victims. 
“Now I know of the help available and I just want to raise as much publicity as possible for other victims. 
“One of the ways I’m doing that is by showing pictures of my injuries.” 
The 44-year-old also said she “makes no apology” for releasing the shocking photos. 
“I released an image of my injury from a gun shot, where most of my shin was lost and only my knee cap was salvaged,” she added. Read More The domestic violence victim has shared pics of her graphic injuries to encourage others to speak out (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) Husband Darren was later found hanged after he committed the attack (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
“I believe that speaking openly like this has, and will, help a lot of people. 
“Victims need to know that they should not put up with abuse. 
“I want them to know that there is light and a new life at the end of the tunnel.” Rachel after the operation (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) The hairdresser was blasted at point blank range in the left knee (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
Since the attack, Rachel has been involved in several campaigns and petitions tackling domestic violence and abusive relationships. 
One of the campaigns she supports, called Drive, aims to give men who pose a high risk to their partners one-on-one support to change past behaviour. 
“There are lots of organisations that I belong to,” said Rachel. “These include Drive, which is going well. Rachel wants victims to know "there is a light at the end of the tunnel" (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) Since the attack, Rachel has been involved in several campaigns tackling abusive relationships (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
“A petition, which we plan on sending to Theresa May, calls on the prime minister to review licenses given to perpetrators of domestic violence and make sure victims are protected. 
“Lots of people have supported it so far and we hope many more will too.” 
Rachel has also joined a campaign by Gwent’s Police and Crime Commissioner, which produced a film on tackling abusive relationships. Read More Rachel has since re-married and is now happier than ever (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
It centred around her story. 
It also mentioned son, Jack, who killed himself five weeks after the attack and his father’s suicide. 
At the time, Jack’s inquest heard he wrote a text message to his dad days before he died saying he wished to see him soon. Son Jack killed himself five weeks after his dad took his own life (Photo: WALES NEWS SERVICE) 
The 16-year-old was found hanged in Brynglas Woods on September 26, 2011, near to where the ashes of his dad were scattered.
